In your video on how black holes are incredibly efficient generators, you had it correct. When a star goes supernova, the force of gravity compresses the core beyond the strength of nuclear forces causing all the fermions to stop pushing outwards and collapse into a superdense object. This collapse releases so much gravitational potential energy that it heats up this material, and releases an insane amount of energy literally blowing the everything outside the collapsing region into space.

The correct statement would be that the gravitational forces and pressure inside a star cause a black hole to form releasing enough energy to make the star go supernova.

0:52 "The Schwarzschild radius is the distance from the center of the black hole". This is incorrect and a common cause of misconceptions about black holes among the general public. The singularity of a Schwarzschild black hole has more in common with a moment of time than a place in space. There is no really consistent way of defining "distance to the center" as the spacetime inside the event horizon is not stationary. What the Schwarzschild radius represents is the area of the event horizon as A = 4piR^2.

To find the radius of material where it correlates to the event horizon, I derived this cute little equation.
z = ~6.2087*10^-27
p = density
R = Square root of (1/pz)

Derivation if anyone's interested:
Swarschild radius = 2GM/c^2
R = radius
M = p×4/3×r^3×pi
New Swarschild equation
= (8Gp×pi×r^3)/3c^2
C, G and pi are constants, so the equation simplifies to (6.2087×10^-27)pr^3
If Swarschild radius and radius is the same, then
Z = 6.2087×10^-27
R = Zpr^3
1 = Zpr^2
1/Zp = r^2
R = Square root of 1/Zp

Let's consider:
Mass of a cat = 4kg
Gravitational constant = 6.67x10^-11
Speed of light squared= 8.98x10^16 m/s

We know that...
Rs=2Gm/c^2
So...
Rs=2x(6.67x10^-11)x4/8.98x10^16
Rs=1.33x10^-10x4/8.98x10^16
Rs=5.32x10^-10/8.98x10^16
And that's...
5.92x10^-27
Or
0.00000000000000000000000592 m
Most known as very, very, very, very, very small
PS:Some approximations in the calculus.

Fun fact: The reason the black hole forms is because every atom has the same gravitational pull, but that pull increases the more compressed together two atoms are. It will also make escaping said gravity is harder. The minimum amount of consistent speed needed to escape a gravitational pull, a.k.a. Escape Velocity, will eventually reach the speed of light if compressed enough. Then no structural formation will survive. All shall collapse inward into the new black hole.
Bonus: the additional compression and any new matter that gets sucked in will cause the escape velocity to go WAY beyond the speed of light, meaning lightspeed isn't infinite speed. Black holes really help with science!
Extra Bonus: Even that insane escape velocity still is nowhere close to infinite speed, as otherwise supernovas won't even scratch the inside of the black hole's surface, so lightspeed is far, FAR slower than infinite speed!

The Schwarzschild radius is never reached. FACT: Mass and Energy are equivalent. FACT: Gravitation is equivalent to Acceleration. FACT: The Lorentz Factors apply equally to Special Relativity and General Relativity. That means that just as it would take an infinite amount of energy to accelerate a mass to the velocity of light, it would take an infinite amount of force or mass to compress a mass to its Schwarzschild radius where the velocity of light cannot escape. FACT: at the Schwarzschild radius, the Lorentz Factors of both 0 time dilation and total length contraction must occur. This means that all motion or quantum activity in a mass must come to a stop and that its 3rd dimension must disappear leaving a physically impossible two dimensional sphere through which nothing would be able to fall. This fact is revealed in the Schwarzschild coordinate system used by Karl Schwarzschild but is blatantly ignored in the Eddington-Finkelstein coordinate system that arbitrarily assigns all but one of the Lorentz Factors to occur at a singularity while retaining the 0 time dilation at the Schwarzschild radius. Not only is such a singularity an impossibility as shown by the Hawking-Penrose theorem, but the factor of time dilation is a direct consequence of the factor of length contraction. You can't have one without the other. Either 0 time and 0 length both occur at the Schwarzschild radius or 0 time and 0 length both occur at the singularity. In either case, it is a physical impossibility. The infinite amount of mass/energy required by the Lorentz Factors is a direct consequence of the Uncertainty Principle that reveals that localizing a quantum particle requires infinite energy to counter the particle's infinite momentum to result. It is this Zero Point Energy that ultimately prohibits complete time dilation/length contraction and therefore prohibits the existence of a black hole. So then, what are the objects that are being misidentified as being black holes? They are quark stars: highly dense quark matter cores surrounded by dense gluon fields. Unlike supposed black holes, quark stars can produce gravitational waves since gravitational waves are produced from the edge of a volume of mass and such an edge for supposed black holes would be within the event horizon from which nothing with the velocity of light can escape.

Now calculate the Schwarzschild radius of the known visible universe to find they are the same.  We see only that within the Schwarzschild radius, yet the density is low.  We sit within a black hole ourselves and see only as far as the event horizon.  This tells us many things scientists haven't seemed to have confronted.  1) Universe is likely not bounded by our 46B light-year view of it, 2) Just because we see 46B ly in all directions doesn't mean we're near the center, 3) expanding and accelerating expansion implications, such as what's seen at the event horizon? what's appearing or disappearing?, 4) We've been told black holes are dense, yet we're in a black hole and not dense, 5) what implications for the black holes we can sense from the outside?  In other words, we're outside what we traditionally recognize as black holes, does our being in one change what we think might be in a black hole? Maybe they aren't dense at all?  Maybe they too are constructed of dense objects separated by (relatively) vast distances?  6) What Hawking radiation effects might we gain understanding at the universe-scale?  7) The black holes we sense are sharply defined barriers between our existence and a seemingly unknowable existence within that black hole, yet our black hole of uniform distribution doesn't appear to have such a well defined edge.  In other words, as we moved left toward the outer event horizon, one presumes we could and would see more matter left, but see less right as the right-hand matter became outside the Schwarzschild radius and we could no longer see it?  And many, many more...

This topic has actually been nagging me for quite some while, as realistically there’s some wriggle room for this radius... not because of the inconsistency of density in the material, but due to the speed that gravity propagates.

According to Einstein, Gravity should propagate at the speed of light - which observations have confirmed.
Realistically (aside to having a cat cluster), we’d probably go over the Schwarzschild radius as gravity would need at least 8.5 minutes to propagate to the center of the cat cluster to signal the collapse in matter... which realistically speaking is enough time for the now colossal cat cluster to naturally attract more matter... or cats.
Not to mention the additional time it should take for gravity to reach the center due to time dilation caused by the mass of the cat cluster.

On a side note, if relativity was also to be applied, the cats would also need to travel an infinite distance to the singularity starting from any point within or outside of the Schwarzschild radius due to the distance dilation caused by gravity... but that’s a different story.

I think there is a small mistake at 1:34. One yoctometer equals 10^-24 meters, so 0.01 yoctometers would be 10^-26 meters, 26 zeroes followed by a one. However, the Schwarzschild radius written down consists of 27 zeroes followed by a one, hence actually being 0.001 yoctometers. Plugging the two values into the equation, 0.001 yoctometers gives us the incredibly low cat mass of approximately 0,67 kilograms, slightly below the Guinness World Record for the lightest cat (around 0,68 kilograms), whereas 0.01 yoctometers points to a rather fat cat, weighing 6,8 kilograms. I think it's safe to assume the mistake was in the video rather than the audio.

No object has ever become a black hole as no object has ever had an infinite amount of energy to squeeze it down to its Schwarzschild radius. As an object approaches its Schwarzschild radius, its quantum activity slows down (time dilation) and its depth contracts towards its surface (length contraction) in accordance with the Lorentz factors. It requires infinite energy to achieve 0 time dilation and total length contraction just as it requires infinite energy to completely still the motion of quantum activity in accordance with the uncertainty principle. These facts can't simply be ignored simply to entertain the fantasy of a black hole. Even the simple fact that gravitational waves only move at the speed of light and therefore cannot be produced by any object that does not allow light velocity motion to escape proves that objects producing gravitational waves aren't actually black holes.

Some popular misconceptions about black holes were repeated in this video, and , by golly, I wish they would stop.

0:03 As you go on to explain, black holes are not necessarily very heavy objects. I believe what you meant to say was that they are very dense objects, but even this is not true. In fact, thinking about black holes as "objects" sets people up for profound misunderstanding - but more on that in a sec.
We on Earth are very very far from the closest black hole, and from our perspective, black holes behave as if they are very dense objects most of the time. This is because we can only observe other objects as they interact with the black holes from afar.
Some black holes have relatively low density. As you can demonstrate with your calculations, what determines whether or not a black hole forms is whether or not the Schwarzchild radius would be contained within the circumference of a spherical object of equal mass.

0:57 Black holes are NOT objects that are "so dense that not even light can escape". People need to stop saying this, please. First of all, density is not the determining factor. It is the relationship between mass and the Schwarzchild radius that is the factor that determines whether a black hole has formed, as mentioned above. Secondly, black holes appear black because the gravitational time dilation that occurs in their vicinity shifts the frequency of light from all objects in their vicinity towards the infra-red end of the spectrum. The light waves become longer and are therefore red-shifted into invisibility. This is why they look black - not because light is trying to escape, but can't. Thirdly, from our perspective, and the perspective of any observer (or particle) OUTSIDE of the black hole, no object, particle, or anything has EVER entered the black hole. Ever. This includes light. Therefore to say that "not even light can escape" ignores the fact that no light has ever even entered any black hole. Nothing has ever entered a black hole. A black hole is not an object - so much as it is a collection of all of the events that occur for observers that entered, but will never occur for us. A black hole cannot be said to be massive, because remember, no matter has ever entered. No anything has ever entered. A black hole is just what it looks like to us when entire events cannot be said to ever take place for us. The "event horizon" is the collection of the LAST events that ever be said to have occurred for any observers outside the black hole.

Gabe at PBS Spacetime did a way better job than I ever could of explaining these misconceptions. Please check it out. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vNaEBbFbvcY

Actually, a black hole is defined as a region in space where the gravitational potential is or is lower than -c^2/2. In order to make a body collapse into a black hole, you need at least it's center to become a black hole. We can use the formula for the gravitational potential inside a sphere with uniform density to figure out what density or radius are required to make the center of it become a black hole. Below are the equations. Once the center becomes a black hole, it'll no longer be able to support the mass above it and everything will collapse into the black hole as a result.
p=c^2/(4piGR^2)
R=c/(4piGp)^0.5

Edit: assuming a cat's density is 1062 kg/m^3, the radius the cat ball would need to be to collapse into a black hole would be R=c/(4piGp)^0.5=317656545383 meters

Correction over why giant/massive stars make black holes, the super nova is not compressing the core, the gravity of the star and the fact it's no longer making energy to balance out that gravity squeezes the core to become a black hole.   Plus there's more than enough mass in the cores of these very massive stars (>25Ms) that they can overcome both electron and neutron degeneracy, so in the end gravity just wins.    Even if the star did not explode in a super nova the core would become a black hole.

Since you mentioned Schwarzschild is German all I could hear for the rest of the video was the wrong pronunciation of that word. Well, I heard worse where people pronounced the last bit like child. Great video anyway!

What’s so hard about pronouncing the German "a" like ah, and the German "w" like v? These are all totally normal sounds. Try saying shvahts-shihld or something like that and you’re are doing it correct.

EDIT: As people suggested, in German actually the d in the end of a word is actually pronounced like a "t", but that’s just a really subtle difference, the vowels and "w/v" are a lot more relevant IMO.

Also I don’t assume Henry to know German at all. But, seriously people, we’re living in 2017. Just go to Google Translate, turn on German, type in "Schwarzschild", click the speaker button, and try figuring out how the pronunciation works from hearing Googles pretty decent voice synthesizing. Or learn reading IPA (not that hard, srsly), open up Wiktionary and type in Schwarzschild, then you’ll find the pronunciation /ˈʃvaʁtsʃɪlt/.

As I pointed out, the word doesn’t even really contain any sound English doesn't have.
(The "ʁ" can be safely just ommited,"aʁ" just becomes a long "aː".)

Either way, what I hate is just doing it the shitty, totally ignorant “American” way, pronouncing it like whatever without even thinking. (No offense, I know it’s a stereotype…)
